title: 106_s148
content:
The Act is titled the "Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Act". Congress recognizes the importance of neotropical migratory bird species that provide environmental, economic, and aesthetic benefits to the United States and the Western Hemisphere. Many of these bird populations are declining due to habitat loss and degradation, threatening their long-term survival. Conservation efforts require collaboration among countries along their migration routes. Neotropical migratory birds need conservation efforts from all countries along their migration routes. Initiatives to protect them can be improved with better coordination. The purposes of this Act are to perpetuate healthy populations of neotropical migratory birds, support conservation initiatives in the United States, Latin America, and the Caribbean, and provide financial resources for international cooperation. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS.

In this Act:
(1) Account.--The term ``Account'' means the Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account established by section 9(a).
(2) Conservation.--The term ``conservation'' means methods necessary to ensure the long-term viability of neotropical migratory bird species, including protection, management, research, law enforcement, and community outreach.
(3) Secretary.--The term ``Secretary'' means the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary will establish a program to provide financial assistance for projects promoting the conservation of neotropical migratory birds. Project proposals can be submitted by various entities, including individuals, government agencies, and international organizations. Proposals must include the project leader's name and a brief statement of the project's goals. The International Organizations Immunities Act requires project proposals for financial assistance to include the project leader's name, project goals, qualifications of individuals involved, estimated funds and time needed, and mechanisms for local public participation. Projects must enhance the conservation of neotropical migratory bird species and be implemented in consultation with relevant wildlife management authorities. The project proposal for financial assistance must ensure local public participation, consult with wildlife management authorities, respect cultural resources, promote bird conservation, and provide necessary information. Recipients must submit periodic progress reports, and the federal share of project costs should not exceed 25 percent. Under this Act, project recipients must submit periodic reports to the Secretary for evaluation. The Federal share of project costs should not exceed 25 percent, and the non-Federal share cannot come from any Federal grant program. Non-Federal shares for projects in the United States must be paid in cash, while those in foreign countries can be paid in cash or in kind. The Secretary's duties under the Act include developing guidelines for project proposals, encouraging submissions from wildlife management authorities, selecting proposals that meet requirements and conservation needs, and implementing the Act. Cooperation is also emphasized. The Secretary shall support and coordinate efforts to conserve neotropical migratory bird species by facilitating meetings, exchanging information, entering agreements, and coordinating activities with existing conservation projects. An advisory group may be convened to assist in these efforts, consisting of individuals from public and private organizations involved in bird conservation. The Secretary may convene an advisory group of individuals from public and private organizations involved in neotropical migratory bird conservation. The group will hold open meetings for public participation, provide timely notice, keep minutes, and be exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. SEC. 8. REPORT TO CONGRESS. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress by October 1, 2002, on the program's results and effectiveness under this Act, with recommendations for improvements and whether the program should continue. SEC. 9. NEOTROPICAL MIGRATORY BIRD CONSERVATION ACCOUNT. Establishment of the Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account within the Multinational Species Conservation Fund of the Treasury to receive donations and appropriations. The Secretary of the Treasury can use the funds in the Account to carry out the Act, with a limit of 3% or $80,000 for administrative expenses. Donations can be accepted and used for the Act's purposes. The Secretary can use up to 3% or $80,000 for administrative expenses to carry out the Act. Donations can be accepted and will be transferred to the Treasury for deposit into the Account. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $5,000,000 authorized annually for fiscal years 2001-2005 for projects outside the US.
